1.1 BACKGROUND



GenOn Delta, LLC owns and operates Pittsburg Generating Station (PGS), an electric power generating facility located in West Pittsburg, California in Contra Costa County. There are seven existing units at PGS: Units 1-4 which have been retired and Units 5-7 which continue to operate for electric power generation.  Units 5 and 6 are each rated at 325 MW and Unit 7 is rated at 720 MW.  The boilers for Units 5 and 6 were manufactured by Babcock and Wilcox and the boiler for Unit 7 was manufactured by Combustion Engineering.

 

The existing Units 5 and 6 at PGS have been retrofitted with Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) systems in order to reduce emissions of nitrogen oxides (NOx), as required to comply with Bay Area Air Quality Management District (BAAQMD) Regulation 9, Rule 11, "Nitrogen Oxides and Carbon Monoxide from Electric Power Generating Steam Boilers".  The retrofit of Unit 6 with an SCR system was completed in February of 2002 and the retrofit of Unit 5 with an SCR system was completed in June of 2002.  At the time that the Unit 5 and Unit 6 SCR systems were designed and constructed, it was also planned to retrofit Unit 7 with a SCR system.  Since that time, the project to retrofit Unit 7 with a SCR system was cancelled.  This document addresses the aqueous ammonia systems that are associated with the Unit 5 and Unit 6 SCR systems.



The SCR system utilizes aqueous ammonia to reduce NOx emissions from the generating units. The concentration of ammonia in the aqueous solution is 29.4% by weight. This substance is listed as a hazardous material under both Federal and California regulations.



In order to prevent accidental releases of hazardous materials and to reduce their potential impact on the public and the environment, a federal program was established in 1990 as described in Section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act. The California Office of Emergency Services established the California Accidental Release

Prevention (CalARP) Program to prevent accidental releases of regulated substances and to mitigate the severity of releases that do occur. The CalARP Program specifies the regulated substances, oversees the federal requirements, and determines the requirements for the preparation of a Risk Management Plan (RMP) and offsite accidental release consequence analysis. In Contra Costa County, the Administering Agency overseeing the CalARP program is the Contra Costa County Health Services Department (CCCHSD).



With the addition of the SCR systems, the quantity of aqueous ammonia that is stored and used at Pittsburg Generating Station is greater than both the Federal and State Threshold Quantities; therefore, a RMP is required. As shown in this RMP, a worst-case release from the PGS aqueous ammonia system would cause the toxic endpoint concentration for ammonia (200yppmv) to occur offsite, in an area of Suisun Bay to which the public has access. Therefore, the process cannot be classified as Program 1. Although, aqueous ammonia is listed as a regulated substance in Section 2770.5 of CalARP regulations, the power generation industry is not specifically required to submit extensive Program 3 RMP requirements, and the CCCHSD has determined that the risk posed by this process does not justify classifying the process as Program 3. Accordingly, this process qualifies for a Program 2 RMP under both the CalARP and federal regulations. 



In order to fulfill the Program 2 requirements, the following actions were completed:



* Analyze a worst-case and alternative release scenario and perform an offsite consequence analysis.

* Describe the site's accidental release prevention program and chemical specific prevention steps. 

* Ensure that response actions have been coordinated with local emergency planning and response agencies.

* Describe the site's safety program.

* Describe the site's hazard review program.

* Describe the site's operating procedures.

* Describe the site'

s training programs.

* Describe the site's maintenance program.

* Describe the site's compliance audit program.

* Describe the site's incident investigation program.

* Provide an external event analysis of the SCR systems, including a seismic analysis and security and vulnerability assessment; and

* Certify the information in this RMP is accurate.

 

In accordance with the federal and CalARP regulations, this RMP will be updated within five years of the most recent update, before any additional regulated substance is brought onsite, before additional aqueous ammonia storage capacity is installed, or if there is a major change that may alter the offsite consequence analysis.





1.2 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



Pittsburg Generating Station is committed to being a responsible member of the community in which it operates by giving top priority to operating in a safe and environmentally sound manner. PGS strives to conduct business in a manner that protects the environment and the safety and health of the public and its employees by: 



* Meeting all environmental laws, regulations and permit requirements.

* Pursuing opportunities to enhance the quality of the environment. 

* Promoting employee understanding of environmental issues. 

* Ensuring that employees are aware of their individual roles and responsibilities.



In an effort to continue to improve the environmental, safety and health performance and to minimize accidental releases, numerous environmental, safety and health programs are implemented at PGS along with on-going personnel training activities that are described in Section 1.7.1 and 1.7.4 respectively of this RMP. The release prevention programs implemented in conjunction with this RMP strengthens the existing environmental, safety and health programs at PGS. 



1.3 STORAGE AND HANDLING OF REGULATED SUBSTANCE



The only federal and CalARP regulated substance that is stored and handled onsite at PGS is aqu

eous ammonia, which is used in the SCR systems to reduce NOx emissions from Unit 5 and Unit 6. In the SCR systems, aqueous ammonia is pumped from the storage tanks, to a vaporizer, which produces a uniform distribution of gaseous ammonia that is then mixed with the flue gas from the boiler and passed over a reducing catalyst to reduce the NOx emissions from the stack exhaust. 



1.3.1 Ammonia Systems



The systems that handle aqueous ammonia at PGS are the aqueous ammonia storage facility, the aqueous ammonia vaporization skid, and the ammonia injection grid/SCR reactor. 



1.3.1.1 Aqueous Ammonia Storage Facility



The aqueous ammonia storage facility consists of a truck unloading station and three aqueous ammonia storage tanks. The storage facility has been designed and constructed to receive and store aqueous ammonia for three different SCR systems: the retrofitted Unit 5 and Unit 6 SCR systems and a planned SCR system for Unit 7 that has not been installed.  At the present time, the aqueous ammonia storage tanks for the Unit 5 and Unit 6 SCR systems are in service.  The aqueous ammonia storage tank that was installed for the Unit 7 SCR system is currently empty.  The aqueous ammonia storage facility is located near the northern portion of the developed property of the Pittsburg Generating Station, immediately to the west of Unit 7.

The storage facility that currently services the SCR systems for Unit 5 and Unit 6 includes three 21,200-gallon capacity carbon steel storage tanks that are approximately 10 feet in diameter and 38 feet long.  The effective maximum volume of each storage tank is limited to 20,000 gallons through administrative controls which include operating procedures that require a check of the storage tank level prior to filling the tank to confirm that the tank has sufficient free volume to accept the ammonia delivery without exceeding 20,000 gallons.  All tanks have been designed and constructed in compliance with Uniform Building Code Seis

mic Zone 4, Uniform Fire Code Article 80, and American Society of Mechanical Engineers Pressure Vessel Code Section VIII, Division 1, 'U' Stamp, Rules for Construction of Pressure Vessels. The tanks have a maximum design pressure and temperature of 50 pounds per square inch gauge (psig) and 110F, respectively.



The aqueous ammonia storage tanks are supported horizontally on concrete foundations within a walled containment basin approximately 65 feet long by 55 feet wide that slopes to a centrally located, covered sump located beneath the tanks and running the width of the containment area. This sump is 14 feet wide by 55 feet long and 7 feet deep and provides a volume sufficient to hold 145 percent of the capacity of a single ammonia storage tank, plus the maximum rainfall recorded in the Pittsburg area over a 24-hour period in the past 43 years (3.03 inches, WRCC 1955-1998). Although the sump has been designed to accommodate rainfall in accordance with the applicable codes, a sump pump has been provided to keep it free of rainwater. The sump pump is interlocked with the ammonia monitoring system so that it does not operate if ammonia vapors are detected.



Aqueous ammonia is delivered to Pittsburg Generating Station via tanker truck. Individual tanker trucks can transport up to 6,500 gallons of aqueous ammonia. The containment area for the unloading area is designed to contain 105 percent of the volume of a 6,500-gallon tanker truck. The area is sloped to quickly drain any accidental releases of aqueous ammonia into the central covered containment sump. Each storage tank has an unloading station consisting of an ammonia fill line, where aqueous ammonia is fed from the delivery truck to the tank, and a vapor return line where vapor pressure between the tank and the truck is equalized. 



1.3.1.2 Aqueous Ammonia Vaporization Skid



Aqueous ammonia is pumped from the storage tank to spray nozzles inside the ammonia vaporizer unit that is mounted on the vaporizer

skid located near the SCR reactor. The spray droplets are then mixed with a hot air diluent stream in the vaporizer to evaporate the ammonia. The vaporizer produces a uniform distribution of gaseous ammonia in the diluent stream. The diluent stream is then transported to the injection grid.



The aqueous ammonia is pumped through 3/4 inch stainless steel piping from the storage tank to the vaporizer skid.  All electric forwarding pumps and associated piping are located within the walled storage tank containment area. The piping between the storage tank containment area and the nearest edge of the Unit 7 building is contained in a covered trench located under the road and parking area to protect the piping from vehicular traffic. The trench under the road that houses the aqueous ammonia piping drains into the sump under the aqueous ammonia storage tanks in the containment area. In addition, the primary piping is contained within larger diameter PVC piping for all stretches that are not within the storage facility containment area or in the trench under the road. Therefore, secondary containment is provided for all sections of aqueous ammonia piping.



1.3.1.3 Ammonia Injection Grid / SCR



The ammonia injection grid provides additional mixing of the diluent stream and transports it to the SCR.  The SCR reactor converts much of the ammonia and oxides of nitrogen from the flue gas into nitrogen gas and water, which are released from the stack.



The ammonia injection grid is located upstream of the SCR reactor. This allows more thorough mixing of the ammonia-laden diluent stream with the turbulent flue gas from the boiler. Although the oxidation-reduction reaction is initiated by the injection of ammonia at the injection grid, all of the reaction is completed in the SCR reactor by passing the mixture over a catalyst composed primarily of titanium and vanadium oxides. The treated flue gas, containing small amounts of residual NOX and excess ammonia, is discharged ou

t the stack.

The SCR process is controlled with feed-forward and feedback control loops. An upstream NOX analyzer measures the NOX concentration at the SCR reactor inlet. A downstream analyzer measures the total NOx concentration downstream of the SCR reactor outlet. The ammonia demand signal, which regulates the rate at which aqueous ammonia is pumped to the vaporizer, is determined from the readings of both NOx analyzers.



1.3.2 Aqueous Ammonia Hazards



The aqueous ammonia solution that is used for the SCR systems at PGS is 29.4 percent ammonia by weight, with the balance of the weight being water. Aqueous ammonia is a corrosive material although the degree of danger associated with the substance is considered minor. Ammonia is not a known carcinogen, but it poses acute and chronic non-carcinogenic health hazards to the respiratory system and chronic non-carcinogenic health hazards as skin irritations or other effects. Acute health hazards are those that occur from short exposures to airborne ammonia vapor, whereas chronic health effects are those that occur as a result of long-term exposures.

Though there is some insoluble ammonia present in the ammonia solution, the solution has a very low vapor pressure compared to anhydrous ammonia, a more hazardous compound that is also used for SCR systems. The ammonia present will not readily vaporize if the solution is released to the atmosphere. If the ammonia evaporates from the solution, the ammonia vapor is irritating at levels above a few parts per million by volume (ppmv) and acutely toxic in high concentrations. A one-hour average ammonia vapor concentration above 200 ppmv could cause respiratory irritation to exposed individuals. 

Ammonia vapor is flammable in air at concentrations of 16 percent to 25 percent, but requires a very high temperature source for ignition. Ammonia concentrations directly above an aqueous ammonia spill never approach these concentrations; therefore, aqueous ammonia has no explosive

flammability potential.



1.4 WORST-CASE AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS



An offsite consequence analysis was performed to examine the significance of an accidental release of aqueous ammonia in a worst-case scenario and 2 slightly more realistic alternative scenarios.  



1.5 MANAGEMENT SYSTEM



PGS is dedicated to reducing any risks associated with the storage and handling of the aqueous ammonia for the SCR systems at the facility. In order to support the achievement of accident free operation, a management system has been developed to oversee the implementation of the various RMP elements.  In this management system, the Plant Manager has overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the RMP elements. An organizational chart showing the titles of those positions assigned responsibility for implementing the individual RMP program elements and defining the lines of authority has been developed.  Each position which has been assigned responsibility for the different RMP elements reports changes that affect the RMP to the Plant Manager who ensures that all affected elements of the RMP are updated appropriately and that the local CUPA is kept abreast of all changes to the RMP.  The individual RMP elements, such as training, emergency response, etc., are outlined in this RMP. 

 

In accordance with the federal and CalARP regulations, this RMP will be updated within five years of the most recent update, before any additional regulated substance is brought onsite, before additional aqueous ammonia storage is installed, or if there is a major change that may alter the offsite consequence analysis.  At PGS, records supporting the different aspects of the RMP are maintained for at least five years.

 

The concentration of aqueous ammonia is not high enough to be regulated by OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) standard. 



1.6 CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS  



Safety was one of the foremost considerations when the aqueous

ammonia storage facility was designed.  The aqueous ammonia storage tanks are enclosed within a walled containment basin that is sloped to a centrally located, covered sump located beneath the tanks that runs the width of the containment area. There is also a walled containment tanker truck unloading pad that drains rapidly into the covered sump under the tanks in the event of a spill.



Many accident prevention safeguards have been implemented within the aqueous ammonia storage area. For example, in the event of a power outage, standby backup power needed for all required electrical systems, such as monitors and alarms, is provided by an Uninterruptable Power Supply. Also hot work permits are required for specific activities that present the potential for fire, and personnel involved in such operations receive appropriate training.

 

Other safety features of the aqueous ammonia storage facility include:

 

* Ammonia area monitoring system with audible and visible alarms,

* Eyewash and shower station,

* Piping and connections for washdown of the containment basin with clean water,

* Permanent lighting,

* Lightning protection,

* Truck barrier posts to protect ammonia tanks and delivery lines,

* Liquid level indication with a high-level alarm for each tank, easily visible from the unloading position,

* Shut-off valves located on the tank fill lines, which will close automatically if the emergency high-level alarm is triggered,

* Local manual controls for all pumps,

* Pressure relief valves and vacuum breakers on each storage tank,

* Indication of tank level, system pressures, pressure relief valve position and alarm status in the plant control room,

* Safety equipment (for two personnel) including: two sets of escape respirators, ammonia cartridges for the respirators, two pairs of ammonia-resistant gloves, two pairs of ammonia-resistant boots, two ammonia-resistant aprons, two pairs of goggles, one first aid kit, and one fire extinguisher. 



These s

afeguards have been implemented as part of the aqueous ammonia storage facility.  In addition, area sensors have been installed in the aqueous ammonia storage facility area and near the ammonia vaporizer skid to monitor ambient ammonia concentrations. Alarms are designed to annunciate in the control room with local audible alarms for ammonia releases at the facilities.



To minimize impacts from accidental releases, employees have been trained in the safe handling of hazardous materials, the use of response equipment, and procedures for mitigation of a release.



To avoid or minimize impacts from an accidental release of hazardous materials, nonhazardous or less hazardous materials is used, where possible, and engineering controls have been implemented. For example, aqueous ammonia was selected for the SCR system over anhydrous ammonia, because it is less hazardous.



1.7 PROGRAM 2 PREVENTION PROGRAMS



1.7.1 Safety Information



The only toxic chemical addressed in this Risk Management Plan is aqueous ammonia at a concentration of 29.4% by weight in water. This chemical is stored in two 20,000-gallon carbon steel storage tanks and is used in the liquid state as a reagent for the required air pollution control systems. The aqueous ammonia is heated and vaporized prior to injection into the boiler exhaust stream, where it reacts with a catalyst to reduce NOx emissions. The potential health risks associated with aqueous ammonia are discussed in Section 1.3.2.



An extensive safety program has been developed to reduce the risks associated with the handling of hazardous materials such as aqueous ammonia. The purpose of the safety program is to protect employees, neighbors, and the Pittsburg community from health risks associated with the operation of PGS. The program applies to the PGS site only. Safety program objectives include the implementation of bulleted items below. The potential for serious accidental releases is greatly reduced by maintaining a strong saf

ety program. Key aspects of this program are described in the remainder of this section. Personnel that work with the aqueous ammonia system utilize the safety program by attending annual safety training classes and always have access to safety information such as procedures for the Lockout/Tagout and Confined Space programs, and other safety practices via the computer network.  Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) for aqueous ammonia and other hazardous materials can be accessed in electronic or hard copy form through the 3E Corporation and are also maintained in hardcopy form in the Environmental library on the 2nd floor of the Administration Building at PGS. Safety training records and changes to process safety information are documented and kept on site for 5 years.



The SCR systems at PGS have been designed and constructed in compliance with applicable and recognized codes and standards.  This was verified with thorough reviews of design drawings and equipment specifications, shop inspections, testing of critical equipment and components, and field testing and inspections performed by outside parties.



The design and fabrication of the aqueous ammonia storage tanks complies with Uniform Building Code Seismic Zone 4, Uniform Fire Code Article 80, and American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME) Pressure Vessel Code Section VIII, Division 1, 'U' Stamp, Rules for Construction of Pressure Vessels. The tanks have a maximum design pressure and temperature of 50 pounds per square inch gauge (psig) and 110F, respectively and a minimum design temperature of -20F.

 

The piping from the aqueous ammonia storage tank to the SCR reactor has been constructed to the ANSI/ASME B31.1 standard.  The expected maximum flow rate of aqueous ammonia from the storage tanks to the vaporizers under 100% load is 35 gallons per hour each for Unit 5 and Unit 6. The vaporizer is designed to operate within a temperature range of 0 to 750 F, a pressure range of - 14.7 to 10 psig, with an

air flow rate up to 6000 lb/hr and a maximum aqueous ammonia flow rate of 250 lb/hr. The vaporizer is built of 316 stainless steel packing, to the ANSI/ASME B31.1 standard.



Safety information about aqueous ammonia, the SCR system and its ancillary equipment is described in the SCR Safety Information Binder, which is maintained at PGS.  In an effort to continue to improve the environmental, safety and health performance at PGS, the following lists many of the specific environmental, safety and health programs that are implemented at the facility:



* Facility Emergency Plan

* Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasures Plan

* Hazardous Materials Business Plan

* Oil Spill Response Plan

* Safety and Health Program (Injury & Illness Prevention Program)

* Hazard Communication Program

* Pittsburg Generating Station Operating Procedures

* Respiratory Protection Program

* Hearing Conservation Program

* Confined Space Program

* Evacuation Policy

* Asbestos Policy

* Bloodborne Pathogens Policy

* Lead Control Policy

* Contractor and New Employee Safety Orientation Policy



In a continuing effort to improve and ensure proper implementation of the environmental, safety and health programs and policies, the following measures are regularly employed:



* Corporate Audit Program - Corporate audits are periodically performed to assess the overall adequacy of the environmental, safety and health programs and management system and to provide a reasonable assurance of compliance with all applicable regulations and requirements.  Corporate audits involve a comprehensive review of facility plans and procedures, walk downs of the facility, as well as interviews with management, operations and maintenance personnel.  An audit report is prepared with recommendations, resolutions and due dates.

* On-going Refresher Training - All Power Plant Technicians (Operations, Electrical, Mechanical and Technical Maintenance & Support Services) and Environmental, Safety and Healt

h personnel receive annual refresher training, or more frequent training if needed about emergency response plans and relevant safety and health issues.  Additional training is conducted on the safe handling of hazardous materials for personnel working directly with the aqueous ammonia systems.

* Daily Tailboard Meetings - Each crew at the PGS facility conducts a daily tailboard meeting, in which safety and health issues and concerns are raised, safety & health training is conducted, or other environmental, safety and health information is communicated.



The Safety Engineer has the responsibility for updating and maintaining a current and accurate safety program. Changes to the safety program may be made at the discretion of the Safety Engineer on an as-needed basis, but are typically made as a result of system modifications, incident investigations, issues raised in daily safety tailboard meetings, or directives from the Safety Committee.



1.7.2 Hazard Review



The original Hazard Review for this process was completed at the PGS facility in 2002. A revalidation of the intial hazard review was performed in 2008 and another revalidation of the hazard review is scheduled to be performed in 2013.



The update and revalidation of the Hazard Review will be performed by a qualified team that will document any changes to the hazards identified in the previous Hazard Reviews and assure that the Hazard Review is consistent with the current process.  PGS has created a written procedure to facilitate the process to update and revalidate the Hazard Review.  The procedure includes, but is not limited to the following actions:



* Review and evaluate the major hazards, process controls, mitigation systems and monitoring/detection systems that were identified from previous Hazard Reviews.  

* Review the most recent Hazard Review to ensure that recommendations were implemented and the overall assumptions and findings are still valid.  This includes ensuring facility siting

, human factors, and external events were appropriately addressed in the Hazard Review and changes have not occurred that would change the findings associated with these elements.

* Review near miss history associated with the process to determine if any lessons learned can be applied to the process.

* Review facility, company and industry accident history relating to the process to determine if any lessons learned can be applied to the process.

* Review any significant technological, procedural, or policy changes relating to the process to determine if modifications are necessary.  This includes determining if inherently safer systems and newer alarm and interlocks systems have been introduced since the process was designed and if such systems are needed for the existing process.

* Review any changes to the applicable codes, standards or regulations that may require a change to the process or related procedures.

* Confirm process safety information has not changed.

* Confirm organizational changes have not negatively affected how the process is operated and maintained.



As part of the procedure to update and revalidate the Hazard Review, a report listing the various elements of the revalidation, including those listed above, will be developed that will identify who will be responsible for addressing each element.  Once the revalidation is complete, this report will include the findings, recommendations, and conclusions of the revalidation process.  The report will then be forwarded to the Plant Manager for review and the findings and recommendations will be evaluated and implemented where practical.  The revalidation report will include a table listing all of the recommendations and action items,  those responsible for the implementation of the recommendations and action items and expected completion dates.  This table will be used to track the implementation and ensure completion of action items.



1.7.3 Operating Procedures



The PGS Operations Supervis

or is responsible for the development, implementation, and updating of the operating procedures at PGS. The purpose of these operating procedures is to ensure that plant operations are performed in an appropriate, safe, and consistent manner. These operating procedures apply to operations at PGS only. The main objective of the operating procedures is to provide a description of correct methods for performing work-related tasks to PGS personnel. Well-developed operating procedures ensure that tasks are performed correctly, safely, and with the appropriate frequency. Adherence to good operating procedures reduces the risk of incidents including accidental releases. All operating procedures are maintained on the company network, so that all employees can easily access the procedures from any computer at the plant. Printed versions of the procedures are also kept in the control room. The operating procedures are updated whenever a major change to the SCR systems occurs and before the startup of the changed system.  Personnel that work with the SCR system receive initial training on the applicable operating procedures, or when the procedures change. 



The operating procedures contain a description of the procedures required to startup the entire SCR system, whether it is the initial startup, a startup following a normal or emergency shutdown, or a startup following a major change that requires a hazard review. The operating procedures also describe the operating limits of the SCR system. Procedures are also in place for shutdown of the SCR system under both normal and emergency conditions. Normal operations of the entire SCR system are also described. Temporary and emergency operations are conducted in the same manner as normal operations. Other procedures have been developed for the unloading of the aqueous ammonia from a tanker truck to the storage tanks, feed pump operation, sump pump operation, and ammonia detection systems operation. 



Safety and health consider

ations for the safe handling of aqueous ammonia are discussed in Section 1.7.1 and in the MSDS sheets. The following features have been implemented to ensure the safe operation of the aqueous ammonia systems:



1. Shutoff valves on the aqueous ammonia feed line to the vaporizer skid, which will close automatically if:

   * The low flue gas flow rate alarm is triggered, or

   * The high ammonia/air volume ratio alarm is triggered, or

   * The flue gas SCR reactor inlet low temperature alarm is triggered.

2. Ammonia flow meters on the ammonia feed lines,

3. Liquid level indication and high level alarm for each storage tank, easily visible from the unloading position,

4. Indication of storage tank level, system pressures, pressure relief valve position and alarm status in the plant control room,

5. Shutoff valves located on the storage tank fill lines, which will close automatically if the high-level alarm is triggered,

6. Local manual controls for all pumps,

7. Vacuum breakers on each storage tank,

8. Ammonia area monitoring system with audible and visible alarms,

9. Eyewash and shower stations at the storage facility,

10. Emergency shower and eyewash stations at the ammonia vaporization equipment,

11. Piping and connections for washdown of the storage tank containment basin with clean water,

12. Permanent lighting,

13. Lightning protection,

14. Truck barrier posts,

15. Safety equipment (for two personnel) including: two sets of escape respirators, ammonia cartridges for the respirators, two pairs of ammonia-resistant gloves, two pairs of ammonia-resistant boots, two ammonia-resistant aprons, two pairs of googles, one first aid kit, and one fire extinguisher.



1.7.4 Training



The Operations Supervisor is responsible for implementing, updating and recording all of the operator training programs at PGS. An effective training program is essential to safe, efficient operations with hazardous materials such as aqueous ammonia. Employees must be provid

ed with effective information and training on hazardous chemicals in their work area at the time of their initial assignment, and whenever a new physical or health hazard the employees have not previously been trained about is introduced into their work area.



Information and training may be designed to cover categories of hazards (e.g. flammability, carcinogenicity) or specific chemicals. Chemical-specific information must always be available through labels and MSDSs. Employees are informed of any operations in their work area where hazardous chemicals are present, and of the location and availability of the written hazard communication program, including the required list of hazardous chemicals, and the required MSDSs.



The SCR Training Program at PGS informs employees about the equipment used with the ammonia systems, the controls and operations involved with the ammonia systems, how to conduct routine maintenance, how to troubleshoot problems in the system, and how to safely operate and handle the system.



Training for the ammonia systems at PGS includes at least the following:



* Methods and observations that may be used to detect the presence or release of ammonia in the work area

* The physical and health hazards of ammonia in the work area

* The measures employees can take to protect themselves from the hazards, such as appropriate work practices, emergency procedures, and personal protective equipment (PPE) used

* The hazard communication program, including an explanation of the labeling system and MSDSs, and how employees can obtain and use the appropriate hazard information.



Training is documented through personnel training session sign-in sheets.



All Power Plant Technicians (Operations, Electrical & Mechanical Maintenance, Support Services, Technical Services) and Environmental, and Safety personnel receive annual refresher training, or more frequent training if necessary, about emergency response plans and relevant safety and health iss

ues. Additional hazardous materials training is conducted for personnel working directly with the aqueous ammonia systems. 



Training is conducted whenever:



* The job presents identified hazards

* Changes in job assignment impact hazard exposures

* New or previously unidentified hazards are identified as part of the job

* Work procedures or practices are developed or changed which may produce new hazards

* New substances, equipment, or tools are introduced that may present a hazard.



To verify competency, written tests are administered at the end of each training

session. On-going personnel training programs at PGS include, but are not limited to the following:



* Ammonia Awareness

* Asbestos Awareness

* First Responder Awareness

* Hazard Communication

* Safety and Health Program

* Personal Protective Equipment Awareness

* Hearing Conservation

* Respiratory Protection Awareness

* Hazardous Waste Management

* Bloodborne Pathogens

* Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasures Plan

* Confined Space Program

* Ergonomics

* First Aid/Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPR)/Automated External Defibrillator (AED)

* Lockout/Tagout

* Lead Awareness

* Incipient Fire Response

* Fall Protection



To ensure that contractors that work at PGS are adequately trained, the following policies are implemented:



* As part of the contractual arrangement with any outside contractor, the contractor is responsible for complying with OSHA Hazard Communication regulations and the PGS Hazard Communication Plan. Contractors are required to make available, upon request, a copy of their current Hazard Communication Plan.

* Contractors working at PGS must be notified by PGS of hazardous chemicals to which contractor's employees may be exposed, and appropriate control measures needed to limit such exposure. Contractors must be notified of the location and contents of the PGS site hazard communication plan. Proper controls must be established to ensure that PGS operati

ons do not expose the contractor's employees to known safety and health hazards. Contractors must be notified of precautionary measures to protect themselves while on the job and in the event of an emergency (e.g. alarms, evacuation routes, etc.)

* Copies of MSDSs for all chemicals the contractor's employees may be exposed to are provided to the contractor upon request. Likewise, all contractors are required to furnish Mirant with MSDSs for all hazardous chemicals that are planned to be brought on site upon request, prior to bringing the chemicals on site.



1.7.5 Maintenance



The Maintenance Supervisor is responsible for the maintenance program for the aqueous ammonia system.  These responsibilities include the implementation of the program, the periodic updating of the program and recordkeeping.  Maintenance procedures are available from the Maintenance Supervisor at PGS. The majority of the maintenance procedures were obtained from vendors or developed from equipment manuals. The purpose of the maintenance program is to ensure that plant equipment and structures are kept in optimal working condition. This maintenance program applies to equipment and structures at PGS only. The objectives of the maintenance program is to facilitate scheduled inspections of plant equipment and structures, enable plant personnel to recognize abnormalities in the appearance or functionality of the equipment and structures, and to initiate repairs or other actions as a result of the inspections. A well developed and implemented maintenance program ensures that equipment and structures are kept in good operating condition and do not pose health risks due to lack of maintenance.  Adherence to a good maintenance program reduces the risk of incidents involving accidental releases. All personnel involved with the maintenance of the SCR systems have been trained and records of the training are maintained. 



Maintenance and inspections of major SCR equipment is performed on vendor-reco

mmended frequencies. The periodic equipment inspections are documented in the company computer-based work management system.  

Existing administrative requirements for the maintenance program at PGS include periodic inspections, inspection review, inspection follow-up (planning and repair), and recordkeeping. Trained personnel perform periodic inspections.  Inspection findings are reviewed by the Maintenance Supervisor. The Maintenance  Supervisor determines if any follow up action (such as equipment repair or replacement) is required. Maintenance of SCR components is accomplished in accordance with the guidelines in the SCR Operation and Maintenance (O&M) Manuals. Other maintenance procedures are developed by maintenance personnel or the Maintenance Supervisor. Recordkeeping of maintenance and inspections are scheduled and recorded in the work management system.



1.7.6 Compliance Audits



Compliance audits are conducted to ensure that the procedures and practices for the aqueous ammonia systems are adequate and being followed. The compliance audit shall be conducted by at least one person knowledgeable in the process. PGS assigns the responsibility for conducting the compliance audit to the Environmental Department. A report shall be created that addresses any deficiencies, along with suggested solutions. The two most recent compliance audit reports must be retained onsite, though this does not apply to any compliance audit report that is more than five years old.



The Plant Manager at PGS has the responsibility for the implementation of the recommendations from the compliance audits.   



1.7.7 Incident Investigation



The Plant Manager at PGS is ultimately responsible for all aspects of an incident investigation. Incident investigations are conducted whenever a catastrophic release of a hazardous substance occurs that requires an agency notification or results in injuries or illnesses that require medical attention.  Incident investigations are also condu

cted for near misses that could have reasonably resulted in a catastrophic release of a hazardous material or a potential injury or illness.  The primary purpose of the incident investigation is to identify the underlying root causes of the incident, and to develop and implement corrective actions to prevent the incident or similar incidents from reoccurring. The incident investigation program at PGS is beneficial to the prevention of an accidental release by ensuring that any incident or potential incident will not be repeated, thus reducing the chance of future incidents

.

All incidents requiring an investigation, including near miss incidents are reported immediately to the appropriate department supervisor.  The department supervisor will lead the investigation and prepare the incident report or delegate the responsibility to another department or employee.  Depending on the severity and complexity of the incident additional employees with specific knowledge of and experience with the design, operation and/or maintenance of the process will participate in the investigation.  Contract employees will also participate in the investigation if they were involved in the incident.  If the incident involves a recordable incident, or a serious or fatal injury or illness, the Safety and Health department representative also performs an investigation. The determination as to the seriousness of the incident is left to the discretion of the Safety and Health representative. 



The department supervisor or delegated employee that is leading the investigation is required to initiate the incident investigation as soon as possible, but not later than 48 hours after the incident has occurred.  At the conclusion of the investigation, a written summary report of the investigation is prepared.  This report includes the date of the incident, a description of the incident, corrective actions taken, the root cause(s) and other factors contributing to the incident, and recommendation

s from the investigation to prevent recurrence.  The Incident Reports are retained on site for a minimum of five years. 



The Plant Manager determines what actions are to be taken to prevent recurrence of future incidents of this type.  The Plant Manager is responsible for implementing these actions and for informing all employees, including contractors who are affected by the recommendation and findings of the investigation.



1.8 FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



During the past 5 years at the facility there have been no accidents involving regulated substances or other extremely hazardous substances that have resulted in deaths, injuries or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage.



Accidents at PGS have been avoided by adhering to the safety and environmental programs described in this RMP, by continually improving the personnel safety training program and by adhering to a strict maintenance program for all equipment involved with the storage and handling of hazardous substances. 



1.9 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



PGS has coordinated emergency response programs with the CCCHSD and the CCFPD. Periodically, the fire protection district conducts inspections of the facilities that store and handle flammable and hazardous materials to ensure that the applicable Uniform Fire Code requirements are being met. 



In the unlikely event of an accidental release of a hazardous substance, PGS utilizes a siren system as its primary emergency notification system to all on-site personnel, including non-PGS personnel. A paging and radio system is used to communicate emergency or hazardous conditions and directives. The Control Room Operator and Operations Supervisor are responsible for all communication using the notification system. If the release could result in an offsite public health concern, the emergency coordinator or incident commander shall notify Contra Costa C

ounty officials to determine if the community warning system (CWS) should be activated. All community notifications, whether initiated manually or automatically, are coordinated with the CCFPD. 



The above notification procedures are explained in detail in the Facility Emergency Plan along with procedures for minimizing the impact of an incident, appropriate response activities for each hazardous substance onsite, and the phone numbers to contact both on-site and off-site emergency response personnel.  The Facility Emergency Plan is updated and employees are retrained as new substances or emergency procedures are implemented at the PGS facility and an update log is maintained within the Plan. 

PGS personnel that can respond to an incidental release have successfully completed training in respiratory protection, hazard communication, Emergency Action Plan, use of personal protective equipment and decontamination procedures.



1.10 PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



PGS has established a comprehensive and effective accidental release prevention program for the aqueous ammonia storage and handling systems at the facility.  Implementation of the prevention program elements, including the safety and health programs and procedures, the equipment maintenance program, the employee training program and the safeguards identified in Section 1.6 will help to prevent accidental releases of aqueous ammonia and to ensure the continued safe operation of the PGS facility.  Nevertheless, the accidental release prevention program at PGS is continually evaluated for effectiveness and for opportunities for improvement.  Recommendations to improve safety at PGS are developed and implemented from equipment inspections, internal audits, safety committee meetings, employee feedback and suggestions, and a review of industry experience.
